1:20 was the moment that it hit me. Why constant speed in circular motion has acceleration? Cuz change in direction also implies to acceleration! (the direction of the moving object keeps changing, thus acceleration occurs!) Acceleration = change in velocity over time.
I love this tutor 😅😊

Very nice video, all of them btw! Just a remark on 3:00. The centripetal acceleration is not inversely correlated with the radius right? A=v^2/R , but v is also function of R. When we replace v by omega*R then we get a=omega sq*R…The centripetal acceleration is proportional to the radius. Also, if we take for example a CD disk, the closer you get to the center the acceleration is going down since your tangential speeds is going down..and ultimately the centripetal acceleration is 0 in the center of the disk. If it would be inversely correlated the centripetal acceleration would go to infinite and the further you are from the center eventually the acceleration would go to zero which is not true. Omega is constant and your tangential speed goes up dramatically and also is your centrupetal acceleration. Let’s find out together !

Acceleration is change in velocity and a resultant vector pointing radially to the center between the preceding and the proceeding velocities for some object moving with uniform velocity in a circle.  This is called centripetal acceleration and as a result exerted as force radially inward tension in a string, radially inward gravitational pull or a friction on the road.

I want to suggest that you have the same problem that I have. Perhaps you are memorizing, but not developing an in depth understanding of how everything is related to each other. Yes you can solve the equations once you see it solved here. Yes you understand how to manipulate the equations in a way that you have seen manipulated, but when a different perspective is given, you dont yet have the understanding needed to manipulate and solve. I can memorize. But the deeper understanding is where I struggle which is why memorizing type classes are easy, but deeper understanding classes like math, trig, physics, chem, so on, are always very difficult for me. But maybe im wrong about you, but with me, this is surely my problem.

Because school is broken lol I keep finding myself thinking why don't colleges make video formats identical to this for their students...maybe it's because they'd finally become irrelevant d: obviously some online colleges do but traditional colleges refuse to adapt.

I recommend you should try to understand why these equations are the way they are. I tend to focus on the concepts in physics. Also making up scenarios for comparing problems help a bunch. Like if they ask you what would happed if x was increased or decreased. Set up a simulation. As long as you know the basics, you can apply them to anything. Also learn how to read physics problems. There’s small nuances like instantaneous, constant, speeding up and slowing down. These can give you lot’s of information. Trying to figure what you know and what you need is the easiest way to come up with an equation.

I find writing down notes of my own interpretation of the concept helps. Expanding on what the formulas mean. Whether that overlaps with what I’ve memorized or not is alright as long as I understand it and it is accurate I can apply it to all sorts of questions
